That's it.

Recent adult ADHD diagnosis here, inattentive. It's notoriously difficult to get diagnosed as an adult, but as a kid they hand meth out like candy. Could get into those reasons but that's just spitball intellectualism.

I was diagnosed and briefly medicated as a kid but growing up poor we couldn't keep up the meds and I had bigger problems as a kid my therapist never knew or suspected. As an adult, I never suspected this was actually holding me back in life. Incapability for commitment, following through on plans, being generally unreliable literally because I got bored. Which in turn translated into a stagnated development especially regarding in professionalism and education.

I have a unique experience in this as a ZOGbot and you can tell those military docs just about anything as long as you make it clear it's gotten in the way of your job and you don't wanna get fucked up over it. I got like a lil questionnaire to fill myself, have a couple coworkers to, and had my gf do to rank symptoms, told them I had it as a kid, here's your free meth. It'd be more difficult as an civilian but persistence and knowing what to bring up outright that concerns you in your patterns and behaviors would probably help.

The zoomie pills help a lot aside from changes in my sleep and eating habits, but they're a supplement, not the solution. What helped me the most was planning out and committing to a fairly scheduled lifestyle, which should revolve around constructive and fulfilling pursuits with wiggle room to fuck around. You don't have to plan every hour by the day like a robot, just commit and force yourself into doing a couple useful things at a certain time every day that you can build off of over time, and leave nothing half finished until at a good stopping point.

It's a real thing, but nuanced and overly diagnosed which takes the piss out of how much it can creep into the days, months and years before you're looking around like "what's my problem?" Good luck OP

Reminder that context is important. If you're asking for advice don't just ask 'This girl ghosted me, why?', we can't understand what your situation is like. Try to help other anons understand so they can help you, add as much (useful) context as possible:
●Age

>>28087598
I understand the feeling as i had it as well, but this is the first obstacle you will face in creative industry.
What you thought?
Probably someone, somewhere thought already, and probably made it. Could be also some underrated gem waiting to be discovered later (see misunderstood cult movies, for example).
Copy without shame. Take notes from why you like to copy these things, and be proud of your inspirations. Take out things that clearly seems like you are just emulating a style. Add your details or stuff you really think it could be made better and with time you will be developing your style. Take your time as well as someone said before.
Then, later on, you will notice that after all is just a big combination game.
About overflowing, limit yourself with restraints.
You are writing a sci-fi story? Read only about sci-fi. Merging themes, styles and narratives are to be made when you got a solid frame for it, or else you risk it to become some post-modern mishmash that can be utter genious or pretentious scrambling (unless you aim to be a Pyncheon heh)

posts.com:
There are many keys to it… Here is an important one.

When you’re thinking of the guy you want to be… Does it feel great, like the first time you played a video game? Are you excited, immersed, do you think the thought with conviction and certainty?

Or do you feel hesitancy, resistance, a cringy feeling about letting yourself believe it, or letting yourself be that guy in front of others? Does it feel monumental, and insurmountable? Is it a faint, weak hope about some time in the future?

Or is NOW the perfect time to enjoy the experience of being that guy? Are you trying to be disciplined because you believe you are an otherwise unsalvagable loser? Or are you being disciplined, because you are getting high about the possibilities and the gritty life experiences you will meet? Are you putting off things you don’t feel ready for, or don’t think you can do, or do you understand what treasure troves they are, what massive opportunities to let yourself be something more fantastic?

This is one of the keys

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28087470
There really is no reason you can’t be happy as you do this. The true, poor goal is for everything to go your way and for life to please you and present no challenges, be carefree, painfree, problem-free. But it’s a great goal to love and embrace life as it actually is. What makes me happy is taking responsibility for things I didn’t know I could take responsibility for, and making them better.

Happiness is just when you fully engage with your life and have a vision for it that excites you, even if just for the short term. And starting to contend with the bounds of what you thought you could do and be. That makes you feel alive. And you absolutely can take control of how you take the challenges and feedback you will get in the process. If this isn’t happiness, then I don’t have a word for it. It’s what I had always been missing and had always looked for.

One of the big problems of depression is you don’t HAVE to get out of it. Ultimately, life is something you opt into. And you can’t force yourself to do that. I’m describing one of the keys that led to me opting in. Which is by realizing the insane degree of creative control you actually have. It should be at the minimum as immersive as your best memories where you played a really cool video game. Yes, real life is far more hardcore. But you can still be immersed in the moment to moment creation of something better. Instead of thinking life is a series of things you don’t want to do, that you have to do, and just hoping to end up somewhere better. Only doing things where success is guaranteed… The ultimate mindset is when you can have absolutely thrilling fun playing for an impossible reward. Understanding that it’s not about that reward, although it IS about it, and it would be beyond words to attain it. But rather it’s about what your life becomes in the process, and the fact that you gain literally every other reward in existence on the path if you play well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Another way to look at it is switching your thinking away from what you have to do, what you’re trying to force yourself to do, etc… And beginning to connect to what do you actually want. Underneath all the lies of depression of “I don’t even want anything anymore”…

I think a lot of it begins with getting burned by truly living life, as we come into the world doing, and then receeding, and beginning to live an artificial, plastic life, limited by our faulty beliefs about what we can’t do. Chasing yourself around, inventing false endeavours, to try to feel like you are still trying, while remaining inside of your limited view of yourself. Being obsessed with making it work, but it never will. And it gets you stuck in your mind. it’s like being in an impossible maze, and the walls consist of things you have decided you can’t do. You’re gonna spend your life in that maze, trying to find a way out, although there is none, and what you need to do is start walking through the walls instead. But not because you have to. It’s only if you want to.

A decade ago I began playing the piano during one of my good periods. I completely stopped a few years later after the piano had become nothing more than an avenue of need. Why do it if I wasn’t going to be one of the greatest ever? And I no longer believed I could be. I was trying to force myself to have a better mindset, and to keep playing, and to keep enjoying it. To practice better etc.

Today I have no needs of the piano. I never tell myself I want to. I’m learning at an incredible rate and it doesn’t feel like work. I only play because I want to. And the rest of my life is the same. I’ve opted in to life bros. You don’t HAVE to talk to that beautiful girl either. Stop feeling like it’s a need. You’re allowed to say you don’t want to. But now that you’ve relaxed… Don’t you want to talk to her? Don’t you want to be good at what you do? You don’t HAVE to. Only if you want

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
And that feeling of need, that ends up killing everything you care about… Where does it come from? It comes from living that false life… Trying to MAKE yourself live a certain way, trying to make yourself do certain things, trying to make your life feel like a life without it being a life. Because you are avoiding something. These things you are avoiding don’t have to be the bane of your existence… It’s inside of those that your best-vidya-memory tiers of immersion lies.

It’s your genius, your soul, that has been severed off and compartmentalized, because at some point it earned you a scar, and you never returned. You’ve likely done it in little steps, and now there is nowhere left you can go. The entirety of existence has been sequestered away.

And the price is all the symptoms of depression, including literal cognitive impairment. The good news is it can all come back. It’s not like science tells you, that you are permanently impaired. That’s just because science can’t help you.

So instead of looking at everything as draining trials you have to do, look at them as possibilities. You have the possibility today, to do things you have always been afraid of doing. You can completely break the mold of who you are within 30 minutes. Those walls of your prison are truly paper thin. And you don’t HAVE to do that, but you should at least sit with the possibility for long enough to feel who you could be as you did it. Don’t you want to then? If not, look at the emotions that are preventing that from being the case. Look at the things you’re telling yourself. Again, you don’t have to change them, but you should be familiar and conscious enough of them, that you could easily say what they are without having to think. Start to demystify the mechanism of beliefs, emotions, behaviours, narratives, thoughts that is keeping you stuck. You only need to look as much as you want to. But would you rather distract yourself and never understand?

Same problem as everyone else: by making yourself the victim of circumstances so cosmically superior to you, unstoppable forces that don't even see you as to deem you irrelevent (a volcanic eruption, a flood, solar flare, the collapse of civilization) you feel that you actually have the ability at all, no matter how latent and dwindling, to do something about it. Because if you're a victim, it must mean there's a problem.
But your vicimization is an attempt to gain control, albeit through a rather sneaky subversion of yourself. Mostly control over your own reeling mind, that reels because of inertia, a principle and a law: a body without organs.
But you have no true control and will never have any, including the control of others via lack, including the perniciousness of mindfulness that gets to me to: when I tell you, you hate me. But it's true and I love you: when you stop feeling like a victim, regardless of if you are one, you start becoming a master, like a human volcano, or a human tornado. There's nothing you can do except win. Methheads found the ultimate cheat code - dopaminurgic maximalism. But there's a better one that minimises losses, and it's called: just stop worrying.

There's nothing you can ever possibly do about the existence of everything that exists outside of your own head, that you can't explain to yourself, rationalize to yourself, and the best way (and only way_ to rationalize things is to stop caring about them.
>just be happy
No. Not happy because you don't care.
>apathy
No. You still care - just not about the insignificance of your own life.
Why remain also so small to yourself? Your free gift that you get when you're born: the ability to stop caring. Your heart and lungs already beat you to the punch in that regard.
The best way to explain things is to not think about them, according to the munchausen trilemma: when things have no ground, everything becomes a ground by proxy: your own experience becomes an axiom of itself.

posts.com:
Call united way and ask them for help. Rent assistance for example. Local community clinics exist and get federal and/or state funding to provide medical care to uninsured/poor. Some cities have medical care programs including dental and vision for the poor. United Way acts as a national gateway for these programs. They know all about them. Getting off the street is the #1 priority for you right now. Street life will demolish a person's mental health, and its only a matter of when. Homeless shelters for example are very stressful. Waiting in the lines to eat you hear filth spewed out of the mouths of career criminals. Crazy people talking to themselves, trashy people talking about trash. Stuff gets stolen all the time. Fights. People screaming at night. Poop on the shower floor. Etc. Get off the streets.

There's a federal program I am using right know called "ERAP" (emergency rental assistance program) and if your state is still accepting intake applications for will get you rent money.

>>28087481
delete social media that's more challenging to you to not get sucked into, and interact with real people more. i think internet is designed to substitute quality time with someone.
also, get into sports to take your mind off of things, which is also another thing the internet tries to emulate. when you're watching a movie for example, you are absorbed in perception and you're in a space of no-mind. the kind of abstraction that you need for your well-being and that you can get through activity (even just a walk) is just not comparable and far more fruitful than dozing off to youtube.

but remember, in order to not come back to certain places ever again, you have to close the gap by actually deleting accounts.

another idea would be getting limited phone data only, and not actual wi-fi

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used to be really enthusiastic about learning Japanese before covid; might pick it up back when I have the time and motivation

Anyways learn your Hiragana and Katakana. This is literally the first thing you should do. The fact that you’re English means that you’ll be able to piece together many foreign Japanese words since many commonly used Japanese vocabulary are just translated English words, especially with tech and food.

It’s not 100% needed but I highly recommend you get Genki 1. Also, don’t be one of those idiots who don’t know how to write; actually writing things out makes the brain process the vocab better and it will help with memorization

It might not help you learn proper Japanese etiquette but see about finding Japanese dubbed American cartoons like King of the Hill or the Simpsons. I bet it would be way better as a learning tool than most other anime

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was reading through Chekhov's works and one of the themes that stuck out to me was this sense of dissatisfaction with life that most of his characters have. Imagining that if only we could move back to Moscow, or if only Astrov loved me, for instance, then life would be good and I would be happy.
I suppose I'd call this "grass is greener syndrome". I don't know. I think it must be a common aflliction among us all. We tend to go after various goals imagining that if only I could
>Have that relationship
>Own that thing
>Be that person
>Get that degree
>Have that experience
Then I would be happy. I believe this is a trap; it's a mistake to live life trying to achieve some end goal, imagining that once you get there you'll be satisfied. I know from experience the satisfaction of achieving a goal is pretty short lived, and then you're off looking for the next one. I believe it's important to find satisfaction in your present life, first. Not that I know how to do that.

I came to realise that it may well be this kind of thinking that most often leads to my depressive bouts. For instance, just last year I was set on a particular job, and certain scholarships. I was convinced it was the only thing I really wanted to do. I started getting strong evidence that it was a very unrealistic goal, and had a bit of a breakdown as a result - since I'd told myself I could only be happy like that, but discovered that it wasn't possible, I became thoroughly depressed.
Likewise, as a teenager I used to get pretty depressed because I was a bit unconventional, and felt so out of place etc. Long story short I thought along the lines of "if only I could act and look """normal""" I'd be happy". But I saw that as an impossibility. It's not my idiosyncrasy that made me depressed, but my belief (1) that it was a problem that had to be solved in order for me to be happy, and (2) that that was virtually impossible

Anyway, I'm just musing and wondering if this is relatable to anyone

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28087960
I just got out of a five-year relationship/one and half-year marriage with a BPD woman.

The highs are gonna be super high. You're gonna feel the urge to tell her your darkest secrets and fantasies because the connection is so strong. But when she gets attached, you become her punching bag - the sole source of an entire lifetime's worth of abuse and trauma. She may threaten you...you will almost certainly exploit your insecurities.

In all my life, I've never done so much I've wanted to do with another person as I did with my ex-wife. We traveled the country, went on fun road trips...she was always tolerant of my nerdy hobbies and liked exploring them with me. She loved going to film festivals with me.

She's also the only person in my life who has ever genuinely said they hated me. She's attacked me. She's manipulated me. And then...when the negatives outweighed the positives, she left. No warning...no fight...no 'I want to get couple's therapy'...she just woke up one day and told me she was leaving and she was gone. I know a lot of people, that's their worst nightmare. The person you love opening their eyes and deciding they don't love you anymore.

So...my honest advice is weigh the pros and the cons. If you have the balls to do it short-term and break her heart, that's on you. If it becomes a long term thing, it will test your resolve in ways you never would have dreamed of and it will most likely end in a bad way. Godspeed.

posts.sub: Am I doing the right thing?
posts.com:
My mind is running a thousand miles a minute as a write this. I am not even sure what to think and the thought of me fucking everyone's lives up is constantly nagging me. Maybe I'm looking for advice or maybe just some words of comfort saying that it's going to be okay?

My sister is terminally ill. She has 2 kids. Both girls, aged 11 and 6. She has full custody of the kids since their father is a complete scumbag.
I am engaged to my fiancée. We are both 26. We planed our lives to be kid free. Not because we necessarily wanted to but because we couldn't. So we decided to embrace it rather than mope around.

Since my sister wouldn't be with us for long she asked me to take full custody of the children. I understood exactly what she said. I don't want to see her kids to end up in foster care, or even worse, with her biological dad (who would've ended up abusing them for profit). She's been a great mother doing the best she can for these two children and I don't want all of that to go to waste.

I asked for my fiancée's input about it and she said she's fine with it so I went ahead and said to my sister that we should start the legal process to adopt the kids since it will take a while with the courts and lawyers and whatnot. And she might not have the time to do later on.

This is where the doubt comes in. I, as a 26 year old guy just decided to take care of 2 kids for the rest of my life. The actual depth of the situation hasn't set in before and a huge tsunami of doubt has started to break into my mind. Did I fuck up? Did I fuck up everyone's lives (including my fiancée's and the kids)? Don't get me wrong the kids are little angels compared to the stuff they've been through. I've babysat them a number of times. My biggest concern is the older one who goes to therapy but she's still very well behaved for her age. But at the end of the day, I'm just a guy.

[Continues]

posts.com:
>What are the chances that my past actions online will come back to haunt me?
It's 0% if you don't let it.

The way you heal from trauma is that you have to get immediate closure as soon as possible; and as you grow, things are inclined to be action oriented than by situation.

***

To expound mathematically(I apologize for the mathematical gibberish, you can fast forward to the conclusion):
What do you think is the value of a day for a three year old compared to a day for a 45 year old looks like?

a. 1 day for a three year old is (1÷365)÷3 = 0.000913242009132 or around 0.09%

b. 1 day for a 45 year old is (1÷365)÷45 = 0.000060882800609 or only 0.006%

***

Now the above check for a few things:
1. Now if you take both their values and appropriate, a day for three year old is 14.999999999950726 or 15 times more valuable than a day for a 45 year old. Following this, whatever happens on the young person's day increases in magnitude dramatically in comparison to someone who is older: happiness, fear, sadness, hate, bravery, etc.

2. A day can be two days, a week, a month(prolonged events such as a sprain, breaking a leg, depression) - this will alter the calculation significantly which is why closure has to be attained properly. The longer you are held by something, the more valuable it becomes(this applies to happiness as well).

3. This is also the math to "Time heals all things(almost)", the older you get the more insignificant an event will grow. The best thing you can do about something bad that happened is proper closure and simply live a long life.

posts.com: Is it possible to make a long-distance relationship work?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28086428
Yes, but you’ll have it x10 harder than normal relationships. Most people hooking up online, at a long distance, typically only do so out of necessity. Usually shut-ins who can’t or won’t socialise. Mental disorders are so fucking common in the LDR online dating pool it’s unreal.

Even if you snag a sort of mentally deficient partner, you’ll need money. Lots of it. It ain’t just plane tickets that consume money, it’s loads of other shit people in LDRs forget to mention too. Like hotels, overnight accommodations located near airports, travel insurance, foreign medical insurance. Not to mention the fucking visa process at the end.

To top it off you’ll need to withstand long ass time apart. This seems easy and doable at first. Especially when you ‘fell in love’ online at a distance, so surely it stays the same when you gotta go home, right? Fuck no. It gets old, bland, and becomes hollow. The online ‘romance’ becomes a waiting room, an idle codependency online shared while passing months until you can pick up and continue the REAL relationship in person.

It’s fucking difficult. Possible, but difficult.

Hes probably worried because he knows his schedule is wonky and he probably has been hurt in the past because of that.

He is most likely overshooting when he's coming home because he'd rather arrive early to suprise you than to show up late and disappoint you.

No one on this board can say cheating as there's no probable cause or evidence thereof. No cheater would SHOW UP EARLY to their partners home.

Here's some tips as someone who can relate to a wonky work schedule.
-Better time management
If he can improve that then most likely the issues here can be resolved, but work can hold him from coming home so that's something to consider
-A quick "im coming home" text
Granted I'm not familiar on how intensive his work is but surely a simple text (even written out as a draft on his lunch break so it's ready to send can do wonders)


I genuinely think the insecurity you're detecting is a byproduct of him really not wanting to come home late and dissappoint you as he can't give you a solid answer due to the constantly fluctuating work schedule.

Good luck femanon! Hang in there!
